flowRoot.flowPara: Global fire models typically described burnt area
as a consequence of fuel load, moisture, natural & anthropogenic ignition and land use suppression.
A lack of information on temporal & spatial distribution of these controls has meant their

impact is largely untested. Here, we map the limitation and sensitivity of burnt area to Fuel, Moisture, Ignitions and Suppression controls by optimizing a simple fire limitation model, using meteorological and remote sensed inputs, against monthly gridded burnt area.
Soil
biogeochemistry
*Tighter coupling of the atmosphere to the surface
-Increase consistency between UKCA (Gas and Aerosols) and
JULES as more land surface types added
-Deposition of trace species to oceans and cryosphere
*More process-based dry deposition schemes, e.g., for aerosol species
*Allow for ‘bi-directional surface exchange’ schemes, with deposition, (re-)emission and PBL mixing
*Designing a new framework for modelling dry deposition, JULES to pass deposition (or surface-exchange) fluxes to UKCA
Atmospheric Deposition
Global fire models typically described burnt area
as a consequence of fuel load, moisture, natural & anthropogenic ignition and land use suppression.
A lack of information on temporal & spatial distribution of these controls has meant their

impact is largely untested. Here, we map the limitation and sensitivity of burnt area to Fuel, Moisture, Ignitions and Suppression controls by optimizing a simple fire limitation model, using meteorological and remote sensed inputs, against monthly gridded burnt area.

IImpact o
Global fire models typically described burnt area
as a consequence of fuel load, moisture, natural & anthropogenic ignition and land use suppression.
A lack of information on temporal & spatial distribution of these controls has meant their

impact is largely untested. Here, we map the limitation and sensitivity of burnt area to Fuel, Moisture, Ignitions and Suppression controls by optimizing a simple fire limitation model, using meteorological and remote sensed inputs, against monthly gridded burnt area.

of photosynthesis
